projects.title: Learning Golang
projects.description: Todo List Cli written in Golang to supplement my learning

projects.title: MirrorWorlds
projects.description: A Multi-Target, Multi-Camera tracking dataset for computer vision research.
projects.detailedDescription: Mirror Worlds is an interdisciplinary project focused on creating a computing infrastructure for research across physical and digital environments. Each environment within Mirror Worlds is a two part system composed of a physical room/building and a coexisting virtual model of that physical space. Users of an environment are not just visitors to a physical space or virtual model, but are also participants whose behavior influences the environments’ forms and functions. The virtual and physical aspects of the environment are connected with one another through a coordinate-based data networking system to enable user interaction with the rest of the system including environment objects and other users.,
projects.contribution: In 2017, I served as an undergraduate research assistant, contributing to a project at the confluence of art, animation, and computer science. My engagement with this endeavor was particularly fueled by the inherent intersections of these disciplines. At that juncture, my academic focus encompassed dual undergraduate degrees in art and animation, as well as computer science, and I was in the process of cultivating foundational knowledge in both domains. Within the framework of the project, my responsibilities were centered around the Unity Client, where I undertook the design of 3D models as assets for visual blob detection using Maya. These blob models were subsequently integrated into Unity, alongside other assets, to recreate lifelike scenarios for detection purposes. The culmination of this process involved ensuring the synchronization of virtual cameras within Unity with their real-world counterparts, the mirror tablets. This required precise alignment in terms of location and height, and the implementation of a script to invert the visual output of the cameras. The ultimate objective was to achieve a mirrored representation akin to real-world reflections when the Unity application ran on the tablets in the physical environment.

projects.title: The Vanishing
projects.description: The Vanishing is an interdisciplinary and collaborative project aiming to create empathy among the audience about the massive gender imbalance in India.
projects.contribution: In 2019, I had the privilege of collaborating with Manisha Sharma on a profoundly impactful project named The Vanishing. Alongside three fellow Virginia Tech classmates, we collectively engineered an immersive virtual reality experience utilizing the synergies of Unity and Maya, complemented by poignant audio renditions of poems by Manisha. Drawing upon my academic background and expertise in animation and computer science, I played a pivotal role in both the artistic and technical facets of the project.  My responsibilities encompassed the comprehensive creation of assets and immersive elements within the application, extending to the nuanced aspects of lighting and texturizing components. Additionally, I contributed to enhancing user engagement by orchestrating a dynamic experience. Specifically, when users encountered particular segments of the virtual reality environment, carefully curated music and poetic recitations would seamlessly integrate, enhancing the overall emotive resonance of the immersive encounter.
projects.detailedDescription: The Vanishing is a project led by Manisha Sharma. It has been supported by external grants twice, ICAT SEED grant from Virginia Tech, and Autodesk. There have been many facets and iterations of the project, starting with Manisha's research in India to find out the level of awareness among the general public about female feticide, the phenomenon that has in large part, led to the imbalance. She later wrote and recorded a series of poems  based on insights gained from the research. Later, she partnered with Virginia Tech to created an immersive Virtual Reality experience that was completed in May 2019.

projects.title: Sondor
projects.description: Experience art through augmented reality. Everyone is living a life as vivid and complex as your own. Haven't you ever wanted to see what that's like?
projects.contribution: I was responsible for the full development lifecycle of Sondor, from initial design and prototyping to final deployment. The application was built using Swift, optimized for use on iPhone and iPad devices, and integrated with ARKit to provide an augmented reality experience. This technology allowed users to interact with museum exhibits in new ways by overlaying digital animations and information onto real-world artwork. I designed and created all animations and motion graphics using Maya and After Effects, ensuring a cohesive visual experience that aligned with the project's educational goals. This combination of coding, design, and AR integration resulted in a user-friendly application that enhances museum visitors' engagement with art through interactive storytelling.
projects.detailedDescription: Originally conceived as a senior capstone project, Sondor has since evolved into a celebrated immersive art experience showcased at the renowned Taubman Museum of Art in Roanoke, Virginia in 2019. This project bridges technology and art, offering an accessible and educational journey for museum visitors. By seamlessly integrating augmented reality with traditional exhibitions, Sondor transforms paintings and sculptures into dynamic, living artworks. Visitors can use their phones or tablets to bring these pieces to life with captivating animations, soundscapes, and motion graphics, revealing hidden stories about the artists and their eras. The experience not only enriches the visual narrative but also deepens the connection between art and its audience.

projects.title: Mobius Labyrinth
projects.description: Barney is a human who has been abducted by aliens to participate in their insane alien game show. Can you help him find all the blueprints to escape the spaceship?
projects.contribution: I played a pivotal role in bringing Mobius Labyrinth to life. My responsibilities included designing and animating all in-game sprites, breathing life into the game’s characters and environments. I utilized Adobe Photoshop to create 2D pixelated characters that evoke a vintage aesthetic. By meticulously crafting each frame of animation, I ensured that the game's visuals were both visually appealing and consistent with its retro-inspired theme. Additionally, I contributed to the game's core mechanics through C# coding, ensuring smooth gameplay and a captivating user experience.
projects.detailedDescription: As a designer and developer, I contributed to the creation of Mobius Labyrinth, an innovative 2D infinite runner. In this game, players take on the role of Barney, a human abducted by aliens and stranded on their spaceship. The objective is to collect blueprints scattered across the vessel, but the twist lies in the labyrinthine, Mobius strip-like structure of the ship itself. With no true beginning or end, players are perpetually challenged to find the next blueprint, making for an endlessly engaging and mind-bending experience.
